title: Sentence Completion
what: Sentence completion means filling in the blank(s) in a sentence with the correct word or phrase that fits the meaning and grammar.
tutorial:
Example: The sun is ______ in the sky.
Correct: The sun is bright in the sky.
steps:
1. Read the whole sentence carefully.
  2. Look at the meaning and tone.
  3. Guess what kind of word is missing (noun, verb, adjective, etc.).
  4. Try each option if given choices.
  5. Check if the sentence makes complete sense.

sections.title: Vocabulary-Based Completion
sections.what: This type of sentence completion needs you to choose the best word that fits the meaning of the sentence.
sections.tutorial:
Example: She was so ______ that everyone liked her.
Correct: She was so friendly that everyone liked her.
sections.steps:
1. Understand the meaning of the sentence.
  2. Choose the word that makes the sentence logical.
  3. Avoid words that change the sentence meaning too much.

sections.title: Grammar-Based Completion
sections.what: Focuses on correct grammar usage, like verb tense, agreement, or pronouns.
sections.tutorial:
Example: She ______ to the store yesterday.
Correct: She went to the store yesterday.
sections.steps:
1. Look at keywords (like time indicators).
  2. Choose the right verb form or grammar rule.

sections.title: Subject-Verb Agreement
sections.what: Ensures that the subject and verb match in number.
sections.tutorial:
Example: The boy ______ fast.
Correct: The boy runs fast.
sections.steps:
1. Check if the subject is singular or plural.
  2. Match with correct verb form.

sections.title: Verb Tense
sections.what: Makes sure the verb is in the correct time form.
sections.tutorial:
Example: They ______ football last weekend.
Correct: They played football last weekend.
sections.steps:
1. Look for time clues (like yesterday, now).
  2. Use the proper tense for the action.

sections.title: Pronouns
sections.what: Checks if the pronoun fits and agrees with the noun.
sections.tutorial:
Example: Anna lost ______ keys.
Correct: Anna lost her keys.
sections.steps:
1. Identify the noun the pronoun replaces.
  2. Use correct gender or number.

sections.title: Context Clue Completion
sections.what: Uses hints in the sentence to figure out the missing word.
sections.tutorial:
Example: He was very tired, so he went to ______.
Correct: He was very tired, so he went to sleep.
sections.steps:
1. Look for hint words around the blank.
  2. Guess what would logically complete the sentence.

sections.title: Synonyms and Antonyms
sections.what: Use meaning clues to help choose the correct word.
sections.tutorial:
Example: She is very generous, the opposite of stingy.
Blank: generous
sections.steps:
1. Check for words that suggest similarity or contrast.
  2. Choose a word with the correct relation.

sections.title: Cause and Effect Clues
sections.what: Look for cause or result in the sentence.
sections.tutorial:
Example: It was raining, so she took her ______.
Correct: It was raining, so she took her umbrella.
sections.steps:
1. Find the cause or effect in the sentence.
  2. Guess what would logically happen.

sections.title: Examples and Explanations
sections.what: Clues may be explained by other words in the sentence.
sections.tutorial:
Example: She likes citrus fruits such as ______.
Correct: She likes citrus fruits such as oranges.
sections.steps:
1. Look for words like “such as”, “for example”, “like”.
  2. Choose a word that matches the category or idea.

sections.title: Logic-Based Completion
sections.what: Focuses on sentence meaning and logical flow.
sections.tutorial:
Example: He studied hard, ______ he passed.
Correct: He studied hard, so he passed.
sections.steps:
1. Understand the logic of the sentence.
  2. Use connecting words (so, but, because, etc.) correctly.

sections.title: Two-Blank Completion
sections.what: Sentences with two missing parts; both must work together in grammar and meaning.
sections.tutorial:
Example: She is ______ and ______, which is why many admire her.
Correct: She is kind and intelligent.
sections.steps:
1. Read both blanks as one idea.
  2. Check that the words match each other in meaning and form.
  3. Test all choices if given.
